member.summary: Specifies that the entire collection of sub-objects has changed and needs to be refreshed. This can be caused by operations that manipulate the entire collection. member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFChangeAction.Refresh
member.summary: Specifies that the entire object has been refreshed and all information and sub-objects of this object may need to be updated. The object that receives this event will not receive other sub-object events.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.AFCheckedOutMode
member.summary: Defines the different modes that can be specified when checking in or finding modified objects.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFCheckedOutMode.AllObjects
member.summary: Used in the method to find all checked out items, regardless of the user who has them checked out. This mode is not valid for the or methods.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFCheckedOutMode.ObjectsCheckedOutToMe
member.summary: When used with , all objects checked out to the current user are checked in. When used with , all objects modified by the current user are applied. This is the default when a mode is not specified for either of these methods. When used with , the list of all objects checked out to the current user are returned.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFCheckedOutMode.ObjectsCheckedOutThisSession
member.summary: When used with , all objects which have been checked out or modified in the current executable session are checked in. When used with , all objects which have been modified in the current executable session are applied. When used with , the list of all objects checked out or modified in the current executable session are returned.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFCheckedOutMode.ObjectsCheckedOutThisThread
member.summary: When used with , all objects which have been checked out or modified by the current thread are checked in. When used with , all objects which have been modified by the current thread are applied. When used with , the list of all objects checked out or modified by the current thread are returned. Only the first thread to check out or modify an object is tracked. Subsequent changes by other threads are not tracked.

member.name: P:OSIsoft.AF.AFCheckOutInfo.IsCheckedOutThisThread
member.summary: The property indicates that the object was checked out by the current thread during the execution session of the application.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.AFContact.FindContacts(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFSearchField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a text search within the to retrieve a collection of objects that match the specified query string.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

param.name: query
param.para: The query string used for finding contacts. When searching the field, the query string can be the full of the contact to find. When the full is specified, the AFActiveDirectoryProperties.UserFolder setting is ignored.

The query string can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must be match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters. To match a literal *, then it can be escaped using the backslash (\) character (i.e. '\*').

member.param: Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection of objects which match the specified string.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.AFDatabase.ApplyQueryDate(System.Object)
member.summary: Applies the specified query date to the current object and returns an object in the new context.
member.param: The new value for the . A value of or AFTime.MaxValue initializes the query date so the latest versions of sub-objects are retrieved. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: Returns the version of the object for the specified .

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.AFDatabase.FindChangedItems(OSIsoft.AF.AFIdentity,System.Boolean,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTime,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTime@)
member.summary: Find all the items that have changed in the of the specified type.
member.param: The of the type of objects should be returned if they have changed. Specifying an identify for any category type (e.g. or ) will return changes for all category types.

If , then items saved to the sandbox but not checked into the database are also searched. Setting this value to is a slower operation, therefore set this parameter to unless you need changed items from the sandbox to be checked.

Check for changes since this specified time. Use the returned in a previous call to this method. For the first call, use code similar to this: AFTime.Now.UtcTime.AddMinutes(-5); as the value for this parameter. If there are a large number of changes since the specified time, then all changes may not be returned and multiple calls may be necessary to retrieve all changes. This is indicated when the number of items returned is greater than or equal to 1000.
The time returned from the server. This can be used in the next call to this method as the parameter to get all changes since the last call.
member.returns: Returns a list of structures which represent the items that have changed in the server.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.AFDatabase.FindChangedItems(OSIsoft.AF.AFIdentity,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Object,System.Object@)

If , then items saved to the sandbox but not checked into the database are also searched. Setting this value to is a slower operation, therefore set this parameter to unless you need changed items from the sandbox to be checked.
The maximum number of changes to be returned.

Use the return from a previous call to this method to find all changes since the last call. Pass to return all changes since the database was last loaded or refreshed. Pass an to find all changes since a particular time.
An object to pass into the next call to this method to find all changes since the previous call.
member.returns: Returns a list of structures which represent the items that have changed in the server.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.AFNameSubstitution
member.summary: This class provides support for the name substitution used with setting the names of objects.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.AFNameSubstitution.GetSubstitutionList(OSIsoft.AF.AFNameSubstitution.Filters)
member.summary: Gets the list of supported name substitutions.
member.param: These filters are used to restrict the substitution patterns returned from this method. The filter will only return the substitution patterns that can be used when creating a new object. Specify to return the full list of substitution patterns. More than one filter can be specified by ORing the filter values together.
member.returns: Returns a list of the supported name substitutions for the specified where the key is the substitution pattern and the value is the corresponding .

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.AFNameSubstitution.ResolveName(OSIsoft.AF.AFObject,System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Resolves the substitution fields within the new name for the specified object.
member.param: The object to be updated with the resolved name.

The new name string for the that may contain substitution fields that need to be resolved. If the name ends with an asterisk (*), then a unique name will be generated based on the supplied name after any substitution fields have been resolved. If the name is not specified or , then the will be used to generate the new name. See the method for a description of what is valid when setting the name of the object.

An object that supplies culture-specific formatting information used when replacing the substitution fields in the specified . If , then will be used when replacing the substitution fields. This would affect the formatting of the time related substitution fields.
member.returns: Returns if the name of the was modified. If the resolved name is different than the current name of , then the name of will be updated before returning.

member.summary: %TIME:yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.fff%: Replaced with the current local using the specified formatting. If no formatting is specified, then the default formatting will be used. The formatting uses the standard format strings supported by the DateTime.ToString method.

The security operation which defines the behavior when adding security rights to an object that the user already has security rights specified.

member.name: ApplyToChildrenParam

para.note: For composition reference types, access permissions for child and parent are always the same, therefore the value of this parameter is ignored. So, if you change the access permissions for the child, the parent access permissions are automatically changed to match the child permissions. Similarly, if you change the access permissions for the parent, the child access permissions are automatically changed to match the parent permissions. These changes cascade down (and up) through the hierarchy.

member.para: If , then the new access permissions are only applied to the associated object.

If and the associated object is an or , then the access permissions for any parent or child objects might also change. The behavior depends on the reference type:
For weak reference types, access permissions are never inherited. So, if you change the access permissions for the parent object, the permissions for the child object are not affected. Similarly, if you change the access permissions for the child object, the permissions for the parent object are not affected.
For parent-child reference types, child permissions change when you change the permissions on the primary parent permissions. Parent permissions do not change when you change child permissions. Child elements that have a parent-child reference to the parent element, but are owned by a different element, are not in the primary path and will not have their permissions modified.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityIdentity.FindSecurityIdentities(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFSearchField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a text search within the to retrieve a collection of objects that match the specified query string.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The query string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection of objects which match the specified string.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityMapping.FindSecurityMappings(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFSearchField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a text search within the to retrieve a collection of objects that match the specified query string.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The query string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection of objects which match the specified string.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityOperation
member.summary: The operation used when adding user security rights to objects.

summary.para: Add new ACE and replace existing ACE with the following behaviors:

When adding an access ACE:
Access ACE for the user already exists, the existing ACE is replaced with the new ACE.
Deny ACE for the user already exists, the existing deny ACE is removed and the new access ACE is added. When adding a deny ACE:
Access ACE for the user already exists, the existing access ACE is removed and the new deny ACE is added.
Deny ACE for the user already exists, the existing ACE is replaced with the new ACE.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityOperation.Update
member.summary: Add new ACE and update existing ACE. Behaves exactly same as operation except the full list of access and deny rights must be supplied or they will be removed.

summary.para: Add new ACE and merge existing ACE with the following behaviors:

When adding an access ACE:
Access ACE for the user already exists, the existing ACE is combined with the new ACE.
Deny ACE for the user already exists, the new access ACE is added behind the existing deny ACE. When adding a deny ACE:
Access ACE for the user already exists, the new deny ACE is added in front of the existing access ACE.
Deny ACE for the user already exists, the existing ACE is combined with the new ACE.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityOperation.NoReplace
member.summary: Only add new ACE if an existing ACE does not exist.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights
member.summary: The is an enumeration of the possible values for specifying security access rights of objects.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.None
member.summary: There are no security rights granted to the associated object.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.All
member.summary: All security rights have been granted to the associated object.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.Read
member.summary: There is read access to the associated object. Read security rights are required to view the object in client applications and within collections in the AF SDK.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.Write
member.summary: There is write access to the associated object. Write security rights are required to the object for modifications either directly or through another action that may cause these actions.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.Delete
member.summary: There is delete permission to the associated object. Delete security rights are required to delete the object, either directly or indirectly by removing it from other objects.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.Execute
member.summary: There is execute permission on the associated object. Execute security rights are required to perform most actions on an .

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.Admin
member.summary: There is administration permission on the associated object. Administration security rights are required to change the security settings of an object, and to force an on an object that is checked out to another user. Administration security rights are also required to or an . Having the administration permission on the grants all rights to the system and all objects within the system including all databases.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.ReadData
member.summary: There is read data access to the associated object. ReadData security rights are required to read non-configuration values ( is ). ReadData security rights can also affect the following objects (see for more information): , , , , , and .

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.WriteData
member.summary: There is write data access to the associated object. WriteData security rights are required to write non-configuration values ( is ). WriteData security rights can also affect the following objects (see for more information): , , and .

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.Subscribe
member.summary: There is subscribe permission on the associated object. Subscribe security rights are required to subscribe and unsubscribe to an .

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.SubscribeOthers
member.summary: There is subscribe other permission on the associated object. SubscribeOther security rights are required to subscribe and unsubscribe other users to an .

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.ReadWrite
member.summary: There is read and write access to the associated object.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.AFSecurityRights.ReadWriteData
member.summary: There is read data and write data access to the associated object.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable
member.summary: This interface defines the properties and methods for objects which support being transacted.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable.ApplyChanges
member.summary: This method applies the changes to the object and all composite sub-objects and makes those changes available to other objects for the user.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable.CheckIn
member.summary: This method checks in (commits) all the changes to the object and all composite sub-objects by saving the information to persistent storage.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable.CheckOut
member.summary: This method locks the object so that its configuration can be modified.
member.returns: Returns if the current information for the object (i.e. its property values) was updated with new values from the server as a result of checking it out. This could occur when another application makes a change to the object after it was loaded by the current application. Returns if the only update loaded from the server was the for the object.

member.name: P:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable.CheckOutInfo
member.summary: This read-only property returns the checked out status information for the object.

member.name: P:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable.IsDirty
member.summary: Indicates whether the object or one of its sub-objects have been modified since the last save in to persistent storage.

member.name: P:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable.IsNew
member.summary: Indicates whether the object is new and has never been saved to persistent storage.

member.name: P:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable.ModifyDate
member.summary: This read-only property returns the time when the object was last modified.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable.Refresh

member.name: P:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable.RevisionNumber

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.IAFTransactable.UndoCheckOut(System.Boolean)
member.summary: This method discards all the changes to the object and all sub-objects since the last call to . Any changes since the check out will be lost.
member.param: If this parameter is , then the check out is undone even if the object has been checked out by another user. If , then only the user that checked out the object is allowed to undo the check out.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode
member.summary: Indicates the type of export to perform when using an ExportXml method. Since this is a bit mask, several of these values can be set at the same time.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.StrongReferences
member.summary: Export this object and all objects it contains. This option applies only to Xml export.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.AllReferences
member.summary: Export this object and all objects it references. This flag cannot be set if the NoReferences flag is set. This option applies only to Xml export. The OSIsoft.AF.xsd file, located in the default x86 installation folder of AF Client, documents the type of references which are included for each major AF type.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.NoReferences
member.summary: Export this object only. For example, AF Attributes of an AF Element will not be included. This flag cannot be set if the AllReferences flag is set. This option applies only to Xml export.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.ChangesOnly
member.summary: Export changes only. Not Implemented.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.NoUniqueID
member.summary: Don't export UniqueIDs associated with each object. This option applies only to Xml export.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.DefaultValues
member.summary: Export default values. This option only applies to Xml export. Csv export always includes default values.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.Library
member.summary: Used to limit the export of a database to include library objects only. Library objects are Categories, all Templates, Enumeration Sets, Reference Types, Tables and the Unit-of-Measure Database. This option only applies to Xml export.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.Security
member.summary: Include Security Descriptors in export. Exporting Security Descriptors will have a performance impact on both Export and Import. This option only applies to Xml export.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.Flat
member.summary: Export heirerachical objects in a flattend style. This includes Elements, Attributes, Attribute Templates, and Event Frames. This option only applies to Xml export.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.SimplifiedConfigStrings
member.summary: Export the simplified form of configuration strings for attributes and attribute templates. The simplified strings will already have parameters substituted and will not include UniqueIDs or point identifiers.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.AppendUnitsOfMeasure
member.summary: Append the unit of measure, if any, to the end of attribute values and attribute template values when they are exported.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.ReferencedAttributeValues
member.summary: Include data values from data references for attributes if their values are to be exported. This option only applies to Csv export.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.ReferencedTransposedValues
member.summary: Include data values from data references for attribute column values when exporting data in Csv format.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.UseMilliseconds
member.summary: Include milliseconds on DateTimes when exporting data in Csv format. Xml export always will use the full timestamp precision.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode.PasteOperation
member.summary: Use user interface Paste Rules to determine what properties of templated objects should be exported. This option only applies to Xml export.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.PIImportMode
member.summary: Indicates the type of import to perform when using an ImportXml or ImportCsvmethod. Since this is a bit mask, several of these values can be set at the same time.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIImportMode.AllowCreate
member.summary: Import and create new objects.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIImportMode.AllowUpdate
member.summary: Import and overwrite existing objects. This flag cannot be set if the GenerateUniqueNames flag is set.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIImportMode.GenerateUniqueNames
member.summary: Generate unique names for objects that conflict. This flag cannot be set if the AllowUpdate flag is set. If this flag set, then the AllowCreate flag must also be set.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIImportMode.PasteOperation
member.summary: Use user interface Paste Rules to determine when to generate unique names or allow updates. You do not usually specify any other flags when setting this flag.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIImportMode.AutoCheckIn
member.summary: Automatically check in all database changes during the import. This can be useful when importing large files which would be too large to check in all changes. If an error occurs during the import, some changes may have already been checked in and cannot be undone.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIImportMode.Compatibility
member.summary: Internal flag set by the compatibility layer to indicate that the import should abide by AF 1.x rules. In particular, importing a global element into a model will create a reference to the element instead of a copy.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIImportMode.CreateConfig
member.summary: Will invoke the Data Reference CreateConfig option, which allows PI Points to be auto created, as well as having their substitution parameters resolved and server and point id's set. Performance of import will be affected when this option is turned on. Note that this setting will only apply to newly created elements for xml import, but will apply to both new and modified elements for csv import.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIImportMode.DeleteOperation
member.summary: Delete existing objects. This flag cannot be set if the AllowCreate or AllowUpdate are set.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PIImportMode.CreateCategories
member.summary: Automatically add categories that are specified but not found.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.PISystem.Connect
member.summary: Connects to the server using default credentials to allow sending and retrieving data.
member.exception: The CommunicationException, and any derived class of CommunicationException, are expected exceptions that can be thrown while making a WCF connection from the AF Client to the PI AF Server or if the server reported an error communicating with the SQL Server. The CommunicationException can be expected in any AF SDK method that makes a call to the PI AF Server.

The TimeoutException is an expected exception that can be thrown while making a WCF connection from the AF Client to the AF WCF Server. The exception that is thrown when the time allotted for the connection or operation has expired. The TimoutException can be expected in any AF SDK method that makes a call to the PI AF Server.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.PISystem.ExportCsv(System.Object,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Type},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.String},OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Exports the CSV representation of requested object(s) and returns it as a string.
member.param: The object to return in CSV format.

An optional list of types that are to be exported. For example, for elements, if the user wanted to export attributes, but not ports or extended properties, the list should only contain typeof(AFElement) and typeof(AFAttribute). If null, all types owned by the export object will be exported.
The names of the desired columns whose values are to be exported.
One or more of the values which indicates how data should be exported. Only and are valid for CSV export. Others are ignored.

The culture-specific settings to be used for conversion of times, dates, floating-point values, etc. If , the current culture will be assumed. If the invariant culture is specified, then DateTime's will be output in Utc time.
member.returns: Returns the CSV representation of the exported objects. The values of the requested properties of the exported objects will be included.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.PISystem.ExportCsv(System.Object,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Type},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.String},OSIsoft.AF.PIExportMode,System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.String,System.Object,System.Object,System.EventHandler{OSIsoft.AF.AFProgressEventArgs})
member.summary: Exports the representation of requested object(s) in comma-separated (CSV) format to a file.
member.param: The object to return in CSV format.

An optional list of types that are to be exported. For example, for elements, if the user wanted to export attributes, but not ports or extended properties, the list should only contain typeof(AFElement) and typeof(AFAttribute). If null, all types owned by the export object will be exported.
The names of the desired columns whose values are to be exported.
One or more of the values which indicates how data should be exported. Only PIExportMode.SimplifiedConfigStrings and PIIExportMode.AppendUnitsOfMeasure are valid for CSV export. Others are ignored.

The culture-specific settings to be used for conversion of times, dates, floating-point values, etc. If , the current culture will be assumed. If the invariant culture is specified, then DateTime's will be output in Utc time.
The file to which the exported Csv information should be written. If the file already exists, it will be overwritten.

An object representing the earliest starting time for , , and objects that may be part of the exported object. Use if no event frame type objects are to be included.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

An object representing the latest ending time for , , and objects that may be part of the exported object.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.
Delegate used to receive progress indication on operations.

The names of the desired columns whose values are to be exported.

The names of the desired columns whose values are to be exported.

The culture-specific settings to be used for conversion of times, dates, floating-point values, etc. If , the current culture will be assumed. If the invariant culture is specified, then DateTime's will be output in Utc time.
The file to which the exported Csv information should be written. If the file already exists, it will be overwritten.

An object representing the earliest starting time for , , and objects that may be part of the exported object. Use if no event frame type objects are to be included.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

An object representing the latest ending time for , , and objects that may be part of the exported object.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.
Delegate used to receive progress indication on operations.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.PISystem.FindChangedItems(OSIsoft.AF.AFIdentity,System.Boolean,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTime,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTime@)
member.summary: Find all the items that have changed in the of the specified type.
member.param: The of the type of objects should be returned if they have changed.

If , then items saved to the sandbox but not checked into the database are also search. Setting this value to is a slower operation, therefore set this parameter to unless you need changed items from the sandbox to be checked.

Check for changes since this specified time. Use the returned in a previous call to this method. For the first call, use code similar to this: AFTime.Now.UtcTime.AddMinutes(-5); as the value for this parameter. If there are a large number of changes since the specified time, then all changes may not be returned and multiple calls may be necessary to retrieve all changes. This is indicated when the number of items returned is greater than or equal to 1000.
The time returned from the server. This can be used in the next call to this method as the parameter to get all changes since the last call.
member.returns: Returns a list of structures which represent the items that have changed in the system.

The maximum number of changes to be returned.

Use the return from a previous call to this method to find all changes since the last call. Pass to return all changes since the was last loaded or refreshed. Pass an to find all changes since a particular time.
An object to pass into the next call to this method to find all changes since the previous call.
member.returns: Returns a list of structures which represent the items that have changed in the server.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Analysis.AFAnalysis.FindAnalyses(OSIsoft.AF.AFDatabase,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFSearchField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a search within the to retrieve a non-paged collection of objects that match the specified query string.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The query string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection containing the first page of objects which match the specified string.

Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The starting index (zero based) of the items to be returned.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection. This value should not be changed between calls when attempting to get the next page of items.
The order that the returned collection is sorted. This value should not be changed between calls when attempting to get the next page of items.
The maximum number of objects to be returned per call (the page size).
The total number of objects that match the search criteria.
member.returns: Returns the collection containing the specified page of objects which match the specified string.

member.summary: Performs a search within the to retrieve a paged collection of objects that match the specified query strings and additional filters.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.

The description filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
The specified group identifier object to match. Specify to not search by group ID.
Specify that returned analyses must have this category. You can specify to return analyses that do not have any category. To not filter by analysis category, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that returned analyses must have this template. You can specify to return analyses that do not have any template. To not filter by analysis template, then specify for this parameter.
The that is the target of the desired objects. You can specify to return analyses that do not have any target. To not filter by target, then specify for this parameter.
The of the desired objects must match this status. Specify to not search by status.
The starting index (zero based) of the items to be returned.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection. This value should not be changed between calls when attempting to get the next page of items.
The order that the returned collection is sorted. This value should not be changed between calls when attempting to get the next page of items.
The maximum number of objects to be returned per call (the page size).
member.returns: Returns a collection containing the specified page of objects which match the specified string and filters.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Analysis.AFAnalysisTemplate.FindAnalysisTemplate(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.Guid,System.Object)
member.summary: Retrieves the object with the specified unique identifier at the specified query date.
member.param: The to search for the desired object.
The unique identifier of the object to find.

The query date used to find the object. Specify or AFTime.MaxValue for most recent versions of the objects.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: The in the which matches the unique identifier at the specified .

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Analysis.AFAnalysisTemplate.FindAnalysisTemplates(OSIsoft.AF.AFDatabase,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFSearchField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a text search within the to retrieve a collection of objects that match the specified query string.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The query string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection of objects which match the specified string.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Analysis.AFCase.FindCase(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.Guid,System.Object)
member.summary: Retrieves the object with the specified unique identifier at the specified query date.
member.param: The to search for the desired object.
The unique identifier of the object to find.

The query date used to find the object. Specify or AFTime.MaxValue for most recent versions of the objects.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: The in the which matches the unique identifier at the specified . If the object does not exist, then will be returned.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Analysis.AFCase.FindCases(OSIsoft.AF.Analysis.AFAnalysis,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFSearchMode,System.Object,System.Object,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFCategory,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementTemplate,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves a list of objects that match the specified filtering conditions.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.
Determines how the and parameters are treated when searching for case objects to be included in the returned collection.

An object representing the starting time for the search. The must be less than or equal to the . The parameter will control whether the comparison will be performed against the case's or .
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

An object representing the ending time for the search. The must be greater than or equal to the . The parameter will control whether the comparison will be performed against the case's or .
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

The case name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specify that returned cases must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that returned cases must have this template or a template derived from this template. To not filter by element template, then specify for this parameter.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns a collection containing the specified page of objects which match the specified filters.

A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". The maximum number of cases to be returned. More than the specified number may be returned if multiple items have the same for the last case returned.
Indicates the direction in time from the or to proceed when returning cases.

The case name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specify that returned cases must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.

An object representing the starting time for the search.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Indicates the direction in time from the start time to proceed when returning cases. If , then cases greater than or equal to the start time (moving forward in time) are returned. If , then cases less than or equal to the start time (moving backward in time) are returned.

The case name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specify that returned cases must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that returned cases must have this template or a template derived from this template. To not filter by element template, then specify for this parameter.
member.returns: Returns the list of objects which match the search criteria.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Analysis.AFCase.LoadCases(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.Guid[],System.Object)
member.summary: Loads the objects with the specified unique identifiers. at the specified query date.
member.param: The to search for the desired objects.
An array of the unique identifiers of the objects to find.

The query date used to load the objects. Specify or AFTime.MaxValue for most recent versions of the objects.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: A list of the objects in the which match the unique identifier at the specified . If the object cannot be found, it will not be returned in the list.

member.summary: Retrieves a non-paged collection of objects matching the specified filters.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.
Determines how the and parameters are treated when searching for event frame objects to be included in the returned collection.

An object representing the earliest starting time for the event frames to be returned. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

An object representing the latest ending time for the event frames to be returned. When the specified is earlier than the , the items in the resulting list will be indexed in time ascending direction. If the is more recent than the , the items in the resulting list will be indexed in time descending direction. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

The case name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specify that the owner of the returned attributes must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that the owner of the returned attributes must have this template or a template derived from this template. To not filter by element template, then specify for this parameter.

param.name: attrNameFilter
param.para: The attribute name filter string used for finding objects.

The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:

item.description: If or empty string, then everything will be matched.

One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.

member.param: Specify that returned attributes must have this category. To not filter by attribute category, then specify for this parameter.

Specify that returned attributes must have this . To not filter by attribute type, then specify . If is specified, then attributes which do not have a type defined (displayed as Anything in PI System Explorer), will be returned, as well as types which cannot be described by a simpler type code, such as enumeration values, arrays, files, and references to other AF objects.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns a collection containing the specified page of objects which match the specified filters.

An object representing the latest ending time for the event frames to be returned. When the specified is earlier than the , the items in the resulting list will be indexed in time ascending direction. If the is more recent than the , the items in the resulting list will be indexed in time descending direction. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

param.name: nameFilter
param.param:
The case name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.

An object representing the earliest starting time for the event frames to be returned. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". member.summary: Retrieves a paged collection of objects matching the specified filters.

param.name: database
param.param: The to search for the requested objects.

member.param: The root object to start the search. If , then the search starts at the .

param.name: nameFilter
param.param:
The event frame name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.

param.name: referencedElementNameFilter
param.param: The name filter string of an in the event frame's collection. Uses same filtering rules as specified for the parameter. To obtain an exact match to a specific element, specify the element's ID using a format that includes the opening and closing braces, such as ID.ToString("B").

param.name: durationQuery
param.param: An array of duration queries that are ANDed together to find the desired objects. To not filter by duration, set this parameter to .

param.name: searchFullHierarchy
param.param: Specifies if the search should include objects nested further than the immediate children of the searchRoot.

member.param: Determines how the and parameters are treated when searching for event frame objects to be included in the returned collection.

An object representing the earliest starting time for the event frames to be returned. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

An object representing the latest ending time for the event frames to be returned. When the specified is earlier than the , the items in the resulting list will be indexed in time ascending direction. If the is more recent than the , the items in the resulting list will be indexed in time descending direction. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFAttribute.GetValues(OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange,System.Int32,OSIsoft.AF.UnitsOfMeasure.UOM)
member.summary: This method gets a collection of objects for an attribute based upon the data reference configuration within the specified context.
member.param: The time-range to be used when getting the attribute's collection of values.

The number of values desired. The behavior of GetValues varies based on the value of this parameter:
If 0, then all recorded values within the will be returned with an interpolated value at the start and end time, if possible.
If the number of values requested is less than zero, then if supported, the Data Reference will return evenly spaced interpolated values across the , with a value returned at both end points of the time range. For example, specifying -25 over a 24 hour period will produce an hourly value.
If the number of values requested is greater than zero, than the method will behave like the PI SDK's PIData.PlotValues method. This method is designed to return a set of values over a time period that will produce the most accurate plot while minimizing the amount of data returned. The number of intervals specifies the number of pixels that need to be represented in the time period. For each interval, the data available is examined and significant values are returned. Each interval can produce up to 5 values if they are unique, the value at the beginning of the interval, the last value, the highest value, the lowest value and at most one exceptional point (bad value and/or annotated value). If no data is available in an interval, then no value is generated for that interval. As a result, the method may return more or fewer values than the number of values requested, depending on the distribution of recorded values over the time range. For Data References which use multiple PI Point sources, the list of values returned in each interval may be greater than 5 depending upon the data reference implementation.
The desired unit of measure for the returned values. If not specified or , then the values are returned in the unit of measure specified by the property.
member.returns: Returns the collection of values for the attribute sorted in increasing time order if the of the is less than or equal its . Otherwise the order is reversed. If a is not configured for this attribute or the configured data reference does not support the AFDataReference.GetValues method, then this method defaults to returning a single value in the returned collection for each of its versions. These are the values returned by the methods for each of its versions.

If 0, then all recorded values within the will be returned with an interpolated value at the start and end time, if possible.
If the number of values requested is less than zero, then if supported, the Data Reference will return evenly spaced interpolated values across the , with a value returned at both end points of the time range. For example, specifying -25 over a 24 hour period will produce an hourly value.
If the number of values requested is greater than zero, than the method will behave like the PI SDK's PIData.PlotValues method. This method is designed to return a set of values over a time period that will produce the most accurate plot while minimizing the amount of data returned. The number of intervals specifies the number of pixels that need to be represented in the time period. For each interval, the data available is examined and significant values are returned. Each interval can produce up to 5 values if they are unique, the first value in the the interval, the last value, the highest value, the lowest value and at most one exceptional point (bad value and/or annotated value). If no data is available in an interval, then no value is generated for that interval. As a result, the method may return more or fewer values than the number of values requested, depending on the distribution of recorded values over the time range. For Data References which use multiple PI Point sources, the list of values returned in each interval may be greater than 5 depending upon the data reference implementation.
The desired unit of measure for the returned values. If not specified or , then the values are returned in the unit of measure specified by the property.
member.returns: Returns the collection of values for the attribute sorted in increasing time order if the of the is less than or equal its . Otherwise the order is reversed. If a is not configured for this attribute or the configured data reference does not support the AFDataReference.GetValues method, then this method defaults to returning a single value in the returned collection for each of its versions. These are the values returned by the methods for each of its versions.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFDataReference.FilteredSummaries(OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeSpan,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSampleType,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeSpan,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation)
member.summary: Returns several summaries for a single attribute over a time range for each interval within the range.
member.param: The bounding time range over which the filtered summary intervals are computed.

The duration of each summary interval.
If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the summary durations will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.
When a positive duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the summary intervals.
If a negative duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the summary intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the summary duration sign.
A string containing a filter expression. Expression variables are relative to the attribute. Use '.' to reference the containing attribute.
A flag which specifies one or more summaries to compute for each interval over the time range
Specifies the method of evaluating the data over the time range.
Together with the , specifies how and how often the filter expression is evaluated.
When the is , it specifies how often the filter expression is evaluated when computing the summary for an interval.
An enumeration value that specifies how the timestamp is calculated.
member.returns: A dictionary of , indexed by the specific .
member.exception: The cannot be .
The data reference does not support this method.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFDataReference.GetValue(OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFAttributeList,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: This method gets the value for multiple attributes based upon the data reference configuration within the specified context.
member.param: The list of attributes to obtain the value of. The returned collection of AFValues will be specified in the same order as the list of attributes provided.

param.name: context
param.para: The AF SDK context to be used when getting the attributes' value. If the context is not , then the value will be returned relative to the specified AF SDK object. The following AF SDK objects may be used as a context: , , and . It is up to the data reference to determine how the context should be used when retrieving the attribute's value.

Once a value has been added to a case's result set, either through the or methods or by setting its value with a context of an AFCase, then subsequent calls to the methods with the same case context will not invoke the data reference but return the stored result value.

The AF SDK will adjust the context to send only contexts that are specified in the property. Specifically, if Case context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to Model Analysis context. If Model Analysis context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to Model context. Finally, if Model context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to no context.

param.name: timeContext
param.para: The time context. If the context is , then the most recent value is returned. If the context is an object, then the value at the specified time is returned. If the context is an object, then the value for the specified time range is returned. For convenience, AF SDK will convert a time context of into a time range, time at case's end time, or as appropriate.

The AF SDK will adjust the time context to send only contexts that are specified in the property. If Time Range context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to Time context at the end time of the range. If Time context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to no context.

member.returns: Returns the value for the attribute.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFDataReference.GetValue(System.Object,System.Object,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFAttributeList,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFValues)
member.summary: This method gets the value based upon the data reference configuration within the specified context.

param.name: context
param.para: The AF SDK context to be used when getting the attribute's value. If the context is not , then the value will be returned relative to the specified AF SDK object. The following AF SDK objects may be used as a context: , , and . It is up to the data reference to determine how the context should be used when retrieving the attribute's value.

Once a value has been added to a case's result set, either through the AFCase.AddInput(AFAttribute, AFValue) or AFCase.AddInput(AFAttribute, object, UOM) methods or by setting its value with a context of an AFCase, then subsequent calls to the methods with the same case context will not invoke the data reference but return the stored result value.

The AF SDK will adjust the context to send only contexts that are specified in the property. Specifically, if Case context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to Model Analysis context. If Model Analysis context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to Model context. Finally, if Model context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to no context.

param.name: timeContext
param.para: The time context. If the context is , then the most recent value is returned. If the context is an object, then the value at the specified time is returned. If the context is an object, then the value for the specified time range is returned. For convenience, AF SDK will convert a time context of into a time range, time at case's end time, or as appropriate.

The AF SDK will adjust the time context to send only contexts that are specified in the property. If Time Range context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to Time context at the end time of the range. If Time context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to no context.
