member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFDataReference.GetValues(System.Object,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange,System.Int32,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFAttributeList,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFValues[])
member.summary: This method gets a collection of objects for an attribute based upon the data reference configuration within the specified context.

param.name: context
param.para: The AF SDK context to be used when getting the attribute's values over the specified time range. If the context is not , then the value will be returned relative to the specified AF SDK object. Currently, the following AF SDK objects may be received as a context: , , and . It is up to the data reference to determine how the context should be used when retrieving the attribute's value.

The AF SDK will adjust the context to send only contexts that are specified in the AFDataReference.SupportedContexts property. Specifically, if Case context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to Model Analysis context. If Model Analysis context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to Model context. Finally, if Model context is passed but not supported, then context will be changed to no context.

member.param: The time-range to be used when getting the attribute's collection of values.

The number of values desired. The behavior of GetValues varies based on the value of this parameter:
If 0, then all recorded values within the will be returned with an interpolated value at the start and end time, if possible.
If the number of values requested is less than zero, then if supported, the Data Reference will return evenly spaced interpolated values across the , with a value returned at both end points of the time range. For example, specifying -25 over a 24 hour period will produce an hourly value.
If the number of values requested is greater than zero, than the method will behave like the PI SDK's PIData.PlotValues method. This method is designed to return a set of values over a time period that will produce the most accurate plot while minimizing the amount of data returned. The number of intervals specifies the number of pixels that need to be represented in the time period. For each interval, the data available is examined and significant values are returned. Each interval can produce up to 5 values if they are unique, the first value in the interval, the last value, the highest value, the lowest value and at most one exceptional point (bad value and/or annotated value). If no data is available in an interval, then no value is generated for that interval. As a result, the method may return more or fewer values than the number of values requested, depending on the distribution of recorded values over the time range. For Data References which use multiple PI Point sources, the list of values returned in each interval may be greater than 5 depending upon the data reference implementation.

The input attributes as previously specified by the data reference in the call. The index of the values will match the index of the corresponding attribute previously returned. These values must be converted to the appropriate UOM required by this data reference.

The input values are supplied to the data reference based on the attributes returned in the call. The index of the values will match the index of the corresponding attribute previously returned. These values must be converted to the appropriate UOM required by this data reference.
member.returns: Returns the collection of values for the attribute sorted in increasing time order.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFDataReference.Summaries(OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeSpan,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation)
member.summary: Returns several summaries for a single attribute over a time range for each interval within the range.
member.param: The bounding time range over which the summary intervals are computed.

The duration of each summary interval.
If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the summary durations will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.
When a positive duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the summary intervals.
If a negative duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the summary intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the summary duration sign.
A flag which specifies one or more summaries to compute for each interval over the time range
Specifies the method of evaluating the data over the time range.
A flag indicating what how to calculate a timestamp for each interval.
member.returns: A dictionary of , indexed by the specific .
member.exception: The cannot be .
The data reference does not support this method.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElement.ApplyQueryDate(System.Object)
member.summary: Applies the specified query date to the current object and returns an object in the new context.
member.param: The new value for the . A value of or AFTime.MaxValue initializes the query date so the latest versions of sub-objects are retrieved. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: Returns the version of the object for the specified .

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElement.FindElements(OSIsoft.AF.AFDatabase,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElement,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFCategory,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementTemplate,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType,System.Boolean,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a search on the element's name within the to retrieve a non-paged collection of objects that match the specified query string and additional filters.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.
The root object to start the search. If , then the search starts at the .

The name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specify that returned elements must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that returned elements must have this template or a template derived from this template. To not filter by element template, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that returned elements must have this . To not filter by element type, then specify AFElementType.Any for this parameter.
Specifies if the search should include objects nested further than the immediate children of the searchRoot.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns a collection containing the first page of objects which match the specified string and filters.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElement.GetEventFrames(OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFSearchMode,System.Object,System.Object,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFCategory,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementTemplate,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves a paged collection of objects that reference this element within the specified time range.
member.param: Determines how the and parameters are treated when searching for event frames to be included in the returned collection.

An object representing the earliest starting time for the event frames to be returned. The must be less than or equal to the .
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

An object representing the latest ending time for the event frames to be returned. The must be greater than or equal to the .
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

The event frame name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specify that returned event frames must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that returned event frames must have this template or a template derived from this template. To not filter by element template, then specify for this parameter.
The starting index (zero based) of the items to be returned.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection. This value should not be changed between calls when attempting to get the next page of items.
The order that the returned collection is sorted. This value should not be changed between calls when attempting to get the next page of items.
The maximum number of objects to be returned per call (the page size).
member.returns: Returns a collection containing the specified page of objects which reference this element within the specified time range.

An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElement.LoadElementsToDepth(System.Collections.Generic.IList{OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElement},System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads the specified list objects and their child elements to the hierarchical depth specified.
member.param: The list of root elements to be loaded. If , then this method does nothing. All elements in the list must be from the same and have the same .

Specifies whether the elements should be fully loaded. To only load a specific set of s of the elements, specify and then use the method to load those particular attributes. Note that if the elements are not fully loaded, then traversing the hierarchy via the property will cause a reload of the element on access.

Specifies the number of levels of the element hierarchy to load past the level of the elements in the collection passed in. For example, a depth parameter of 2 would indicate that all child elements and grandchild elements of the specified elements would be loaded.
Specifies the maximum number of objects to load. Once the maximum number of objects is reached, the load will terminate.
member.returns: The list of elements returned is a list of all child elements loaded at all depths. Even though each in the list are loaded, they are not included in the returned list.

The maximum number of levels to traverse up the parent hierarchy.
If , then the parent of the elements will be fully loaded. You should fully load the parent if you will be accessing information about the target that is not a simple property value.
member.returns: Returns list of parent elements that were loaded. It does not include the elements from the specified list of elements passed into this method.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementTemplate.FindElementTemplates(OSIsoft.AF.AFDatabase,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFSearchField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a text search within the to retrieve a collection of objects that match the specified query string.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The query string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection of objects which match the specified string.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementTemplate.LoadElementTemplates(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.Guid[],System.Object)
member.summary: Loads the objects with the specified unique identifiers at the specified query date.
member.param: The to search for the desired objects.
An array of the unique identifiers of the objects to find.

The query date used to load the objects. Specify or AFTime.MaxValue for most recent versions of the objects.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: A list of the objects in the which match the unique identifiers at the specified . If the object cannot be found, it will not be returned in the list.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType
member.summary: This is an enumeration that defines the possible values used when you specify the type of an element.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType.None
member.summary: The element type is not defined. This is the default value for new element templates and elements without a template.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType.Other
member.summary: The element type is something other than one of the system-defined types. This type is to be used when one of the other system-defined types is not adequate.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType.Node
member.summary: The type of the element is a Node.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType.Measurement
member.summary: The type of the element is a Measurement. A measurement is normally used for an element which is used to measure values of another element (i.e. a meter).

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType.Flow
member.summary: The type of the element is a Flow. A flow is normally used to represent the flow of material or information between two elements.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType.Transfer
member.summary: The type of the element is a special kind of a time-based flow which is called a Transfer.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType.Boundary
member.summary: The type of the element is a Boundary. Elements of this type do not usually participate in any model analysis and are considered boundaries to the model.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType.PIPoint
member.summary: The type of the element is a PIPoint. Elements of this type are used to represent a PIPoint in a PIServer as an . User's should not create elements with this type.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementType.Any
member.summary: The allowed element type for can be any of the defined types. This type is only allowed when setting the allowed element types for connection port. This type cannot be used when setting the type of an element.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFEnumerationSet.FindEnumerationSets(OSIsoft.AF.AFDatabase,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFSearchField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a text search within the to retrieve a collection of objects that match the specified query string.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The query string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection of objects which match the specified string.

member.summary: With a strong reference, an will exist as long as it has one or more strongly related parents or belongs to a relationship.

member.summary: A weak reference is used when the parent does not want to define the lifetime of a child .

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFReferenceStrength.Composition
member.summary: A composition reference means the parent solely defines and owns the child . In this type of relationship, a child may only be contained in one composition parent relationship and deleting the parent will delete the child .

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFReferenceType.FindReferenceType(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.Guid,System.Object)
member.summary: Retrieves the object with the specified unique identifier at the specified query date.
member.param: The to search for the desired object.
The unique identifier of the object to find.

The query date used to find the object. Specify or AFTime.MaxValue for most recent versions of the objects.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: The in the which matches the unique identifier at the specified .

The query string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection of objects which match the specified string.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFValues.Summaries(OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeSpan,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation)
member.summary: Returns several summaries for this set of values over a time range for each interval within the range.
member.param: The bounding time range over which the summary intervals are computed.

param.name: summaryDuration
param.para: The duration of each summary interval. If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the summary durations will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.

When a positive duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the summary intervals.

If a negative duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the summary intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the summary duration sign.

member.param: A flag which specifies one or more summaries to compute for each interval over the time range
Specifies the method of evaluating the data over the time range.
A flag indicating what how to calculates a timestamp for each interval.
member.returns: A dictionary of , indexed by the specific .

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFVersion.Create(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new version of an object at the specified effective date.
member.param:
The date that the new version of the object goes into effect.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
The comment for the new version of the object. The maximum length of this parameter is 1000 characters.
member.returns: Returns the newly created version of the owning object.
member.exception: An object version at the specified already exists.

member.summary: This interface defines the properties and methods for objects which support being versioned.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Asset.IAFVersionable.ApplyQueryDate(System.Object)
member.summary: Applies the specified query date to the current object and returns an object in the new context.
member.param: The new value for the . A value of or AFTime.MaxValue initializes the query date so the latest versions of sub-objects are retrieved. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: Returns the version of the object for the specified .

member.summary: This read-only property returns the date used to retrieve the version of an object.

The bounding time for the evaluation period.
The length of the calculation interval. A value will be returned for each interval within the specified time range.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis
member.summary: Defines the possible calculation options when performing summary calculations over time-series data.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis.TimeWeighted
member.summary: Weight the values in the calculation by the time over which they apply. Interpolation is based on whether the attribute is stepped. Interpolated events are generated at the boundaries if necessary.

summary.para: Evaluate values with equal weighting for each event. No interpolation is done. There must be at least one event within the time range to perform a successful calculation. Two events are required for standard deviation. In handling events at the boundary of the calculation, the AFSDK uses following rules:
1) use events at both boundaries when there is only one calculation interval;
2) include events at start time in multiple intervals and the intervals are in ascending time order;
3) include events at the end time in multiple intervals and the intervals are in descending time order.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis.TimeWeightedContinuous
member.summary: Apply weighting as in TimeWeighted, but do all interpolation between values as if they represent continuous data, (standard interpolation) regardless of whether the attribute is stepped.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis.TimeWeightedDiscrete
member.summary: Apply weighting as in TimeWeighted but interpolation between values is performed as if they represent discrete, unrelated values (stair step plot) regardless of the attribute is stepped.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis.EventWeightedExcludeMostRecentEvent
member.summary: The calculation behaves the same as EventWeighted, except in the handling of events at the boundary of summary intervals in a multiple intervals calculation. Use this option to prevent events at the intervals boundary from being double count at both intervals. With this option, events at the end time (most recent time) of an interval is not used in that interval.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis.EventWeightedExcludeEarliestEvent
member.summary: Similar to the option EventWeightedExcludeMostRecentEvent. Events at the start time(earliest time) of an interval is not used in that interval.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis.EventWeightedIncludeBothEnds
member.summary: Events at both ends of the interval boundaries are included in the event weighted calculation.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFData.FilteredSummaries(OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeSpan,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSampleType,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeSpan,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation)
member.summary: This method, when supplied a filter expression that evaluates to true or false, evaluates it over the passed time range. For the time ranges where the expression evaluates to true, the method calculates the requested summaries on the source attribute.
member.param: The bounding time range over which the filtered summary intervals are computed.

param.name: summaryDuration
param.para: The duration of each summary interval. If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the summary durations will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.

When a positive duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the summary intervals.

If a negative duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the summary intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the summary duration sign.

member.param: A string containing a filter expression. Expression variables are relative to the attribute. Use '.' to reference the containing attribute.
A flag which specifies one or more summaries to compute for each interval over the time range
Specifies the method of evaluating the data over the time range.
Together with the , specifies how and how often the filter expression is evaluated.
When the is , it specifies how often the filter expression is evaluated when computing the summary for an interval.
An enumeration value that specifies how the timestamp is calculated.
member.returns: A dictionary of , indexed by the specific .
member.exception: The cannot be .
The data reference does not support this method.

param.para: The Sample interval. If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the time intervals will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.

When a positive interval is specified, the interval calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the interval repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the calculation intervals.

If a negative interval is specified, the interval calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the interval repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the calculation intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the interval sign.

member.param: The desired unit of measure for the returned values. If , then the values are returned in the unit of measure specified by the associated attribute's property.

A string containing a filter expression. Expression variables are relative to the attribute. Use '.' to reference the containing attribute. A or empty string indicates no filtering. If the attribute does not support the option, the filter will be ignored.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFDataCache
member.summary: An manages a collection of s via cache enabled objects and will can automatically monitor for new data changes.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFDataCache.#ctor
member.summary: Create new instance of .

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFDataCache.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create new instance of with a initial capacity set.
member.param: Specifies the initial capacity of the number of AFAttributes to be managed.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFDataCache.Add(System.Collections.Generic.IList{OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFAttribute},OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFDataCacheUpdateOption)
member.summary: Adds a list of objects to be managed by . The AFAttributes are reference counted. Adding AFAttribute that is already in the AFDataCache will increment the reference count and not generate error. Adding the same AFAttribute multiple times will require the same number of Remove call to actually remove the AFAttribute from the AFDataCache.
member.param: List of objects to be added to the .

Specifies whether the will automatically populate the cache with data pipe events. If the application is the main data source and will be actively writing data to the AFAttributes, then use "Manual" update option when adding these AFAttributes to the AFDataCache. The update option of an existing AFAttribute in the AFDataCache cannot be changed once the item is added to the AFDataCache. Change of the update option for an attribute can only be accomplished with calling Remove and then Add method.
member.returns: An instance containing a collection of objects corresponding to the passed AFAttributes. These AFData objects are cache aware so that data access methods called from them will attempt to retrieve the data from the cache. If the requested data range is not in the cache, then the data will be retrieved via the normal channel. Any errors that occurred when adding the AFAttributes to the data cache are returned in the error collection of the AFKeyedResults.

member.name: P:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFDataCache.Attributes
member.summary: The list of items being cached.c

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFDataPipeAction.Update
member.summary: The event represents an update to the time series. If is specified then that value is replaced in the time series by this event. If is and there is an existing data value with the same timestamp as this event, then this event represents a replacement of that value. If there is no data value in the time series whose timestamp matches this event, then this event should be treated like an (this can occur when the data source cannot distinguish between data insertion and data replacement).

member.summary: The event represents the addition of a new data value at the end of the time series.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFDataPipeAction.Refresh

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFDataPipeAction.Insert

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFEventHorizonMode
member.summary: EventHorizonMode specifies what events are returned by the datapipe at the GetUpdateEvent/GetObserverEvents calls based on the timestamp of the events.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFEventHorizonMode.TimeOffset
member.summary: The datapipe gets new events starting at signup time + EventHorizonOffset. At each GetUpdateEvent/GetObserverEvents call, datapipe returns events up to current time + EventHorizonOffset.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFEventHorizonMode.TimeOffsetWithOutsideEvent
member.summary: The datapipe gets new events starting at signup time + EventHorizonOffset. In addition, datapipe could return the next event after the current time + EventHorizonOffset at the GetUpdateEvent/GetObserverEvents call if there is an outside event available. Note that once the outside event is returned via GetUpdateEvent call, the same event will not be returned in the next GetUpdateEvent/GetObserverEvents call even though the event time is greater than current time + EventHorizonOffset.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFEventHorizonMode.EndOfStream
member.summary: The datapipe gets new events starting at the end of stream when signup. EventHorizonOffset is not used. At each GetUpdateEvents/GetObserverEvents call, datapipe returns new end of stream events since the last call.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFListData.EndOfStream
member.summary: Get the end-of-stream value for each attribute in this list.
member.returns: Returns an list, one for each attribute in this list. If AFValue.IsGood returned by the data reference is , then the returned value is converted to the default UOM of the attribute and proper Type. The timestamp of the value will indicate the time of the recorded event. In the case of calculation based data references, it will normally indicate the closest input value's recorded value timestamp.

member.summary: This method, when supplied a filter expression that evaluates to true or false, evaluates it over the passed time range. For the time ranges where the expression evaluates to true, the method calculates the requested summaries on the source attribute.
member.param: The bounding time range over which the filtered summary intervals are computed.

param.name: summaryDuration
param.para: The duration of each summary interval. If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the summary durations will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.

When a positive duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the summary intervals.

If a negative duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the summary intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the summary duration sign.

member.param: A string containing a filter expression. Expression variables are relative to the attribute. Use '.' to reference the containing attribute.
A flag which specifies one or more summaries to compute for each interval over the time range
Specifies the method of evaluating the data over the time range.
Together with the , specifies how and how often the filter expression is evaluated.
When the is , it specifies how often the filter expression is evaluated when computing the summary for an interval.
An enumeration value that specifies how the timestamp is calculated.
Contains the paging configuration parameters for the request.

returns.para: An enumerable of for each in the list. The results are not guaranteed to match the order of the , and duplicate attributes in the list will not produce a duplicate result. The results can be mapped back to the corresponding attribute using the property on each result.

The order of the results are predictable; however, if you need the results in the same order as the attribute list, then consider using a dictionary keyed by attribute to construct a list in the same order.

The attributes in the list are broken up by data reference. If the data reference supports bulk calls, then the bulk call is used to improve performance and reduce roundtrips to the server. PI Point attributes are then broken up a second time by their corresponding PI Data Archive. A bulk call is made against each PI Data Archive in parallel. The results are made available as they are returned from the PI Data Archive in the order that the bulk calls were made.
The following example shows a list of attributes including duplicates from three different PI Data Archives, and two table lookups:
This table shows the order that the results would be returned:

Since the first attribute is on the Contoso PI Data Archive, it is the first PI Data Archive to receive a bulk call; therefore, all Contoso attributes will be returned first. Duplicate attributes do not produce a duplicate result, so the duplicate Contoso Lobby Room Temperature does not produce a second return value. After the Contoso attributes have been returned, the Northwind attributes are returned followed by the AdventureWorks attributes.
After attributes supporting bulk calls have been returned, the remaining attributes are iterated and evaluated, so the table lookups are returned last in the order they were in the original list.

para.note: Several factors can cause the values to come back in a different order, so a dictionary should be used to restructure the results if order is important. If an error occurs or the request range spans multiple element versions, the SDK will fall back to an iterative approach. This would cause the PI Point attributes to be returned in the same order as they were in the list. Finally, calls that include a filter expression that resolve differently for each attribute such as "'.' > 1" will also cause the SDK to fall back to an iterative approach.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFListData.InterpolatedValue(OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTime)
member.summary: Returns a interpolated value for each attribute in this list based on the passed time.
member.param: The time at which the value is desired.
member.returns: Returns an list, one for each attribute in this list. If AFValue.IsGood returned by the data reference is , then the returned value is converted to the default UOM of the attribute and proper Type. The timestamp of each value will be at the requested time, with one exception where the request time is at or after AFTime.MaxValue, which will return the end-of-stream value for each attribute with the end-of-stream timestamp.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFListData.InterpolatedValues(OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeSpan,System.String,System.Boolean,OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIPagingConfiguration)
member.summary: Retrieves interpolated values over the specified time range at the specified sampling interval.
member.param: The bounding time range for the interpolated values request. If the is earlier than the , the resulting values will be in time-ascending order, otherwise they will be in time-descending order.

param.name: interval
param.para: The Sample interval. If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the time intervals will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.

When a positive interval is specified, the interval calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the interval repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the calculation intervals.

If a negative interval is specified, the interval calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the interval repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the calculation intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the interval sign.

member.param: A filter expression that follows the performance equation syntax.

Specify to indicate that values which fail the filter criteria are present in the returned data at the times where they occurred with a value set to a "Filtered" enumeration value with bad status. Repeated consecutive failures are omitted.
Contains the paging configuration parameters for the request.

returns.para: An enumerable of for each in the list. The results are not guaranteed to match the order of the , and duplicate attributes in the list will not produce a duplicate result. The results can be mapped back to the corresponding attribute using the property on each result.

para.note: Results are available for enumeration as they are returned from the data source for better performance.

The returned enumerable collection can be enumerated one time. As the collection is enumerated, the internal data structures are disposed. Any attempt to reset or enumerate a second time will result in an exception.

returns.para: The order of the results are predictable; however, if you need the results in the same order as the attribute list, then consider using a dictionary keyed by attribute to construct a list in the same order.

The attributes in the list are broken up by data reference. If the data reference supports bulk calls, then the bulk call is used to improve performance and reduce roundtrips to the server. PI Point attributes are then broken up a second time by their corresponding PI Data Archive. A bulk call is made against each PI Data Archive in parallel. The results are made available as they are returned from the PI Data Archive in the order that the bulk calls were made.
The following example shows a list of attributes including duplicates from three different PI Data Archives, and two table lookups:
This table shows the order that the results would be returned:

Since the first attribute is on the Contoso PI Data Archive, it is the first PI Data Archive to receive a bulk call; therefore, all Contoso attributes will be returned first. Duplicate attributes do not produce a duplicate result, so the duplicate Contoso Lobby Room Temperature does not produce a second return value. After the Contoso attributes have been returned, the Northwind attributes are returned followed by the AdventureWorks attributes.
After attributes supporting bulk calls have been returned, the remaining attributes are iterated and evaluated, so the table lookups are returned last in the order they were in the original list.

para.note: Several factors can cause the values to come back in a different order, so a dictionary should be used to restructure the results if order is important. If an error occurs or the request range spans multiple element versions, the SDK will fall back to an iterative approach. This would cause the PI Point attributes to be returned in the same order as they were in the list. Finally, calls that include a filter expression that resolve differently for each attribute such as "'.' > 1" will also cause the SDK to fall back to an iterative approach.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFRetrievalMode
member.summary: Defines the possible options for retrieving recorded values from an attribute.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFRetrievalMode.Auto
member.summary: Automatically determine the best retrieval mode.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFRetrievalMode.AtOrBefore
member.summary: Return a recorded value at the passed time or if no value exists at that time, the previous recorded value.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFRetrievalMode.Before
member.summary: Return the first recorded value before the passed time.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFRetrievalMode.AtOrAfter
member.summary: Return a recorded value at the passed time or if no value exists at that time, the next recorded value.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFRetrievalMode.After
member.summary: Return the first recorded value after the passed time.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFRetrievalMode.Exact
member.summary: Return a recorded value at the passed time or return an error if none exists.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSampleType
member.summary: Defines the evaluation of an expression over a time range.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSampleType.ExpressionRecordedValues
member.summary: Sampling / evaluation is done based on the archive events of all attributes used in the expression. The expression is evaluated at each of the timestamps of these retrieved events. This sampling algorithm is sometimes referred to as natural or event-based.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSampleType.Interval
member.summary: Sampling / evaluation is done based on a passed expression interval. This is sometimes referred to as evenly-spaced evaluation. This option is only supported for PI Points on PI Data Archive version 3.4 and above.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes
member.summary: Flags to indicate which summary type calculation(s) should be performed.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.None
member.summary: A summary type is not specified.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.Total
member.summary: A totalization over the time range.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.Average
member.summary: The average value over the time range.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.Minimum
member.summary: The minimum value over the time range.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.Maximum
member.summary: The maximum value over the time range.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.Range
member.summary: The range of values over the time range (Maximum-Minimum)

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.StdDev
member.summary: The standard deviation over the time range.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.PopulationStdDev
member.summary: The population standard deviation over the time range.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.Count
member.summary: The sum of event count over the time range when calculation basis is event weighted. The sum of event time duration over the time range when calculation basis is time weighted.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.PercentGood
member.summary: Percent of data with good value during the calculation period. For time weighted calculations, the percentage is based on time. For event weighted calculations, the percent is based on event count.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.All
member.summary: A convenience for requesting all available summary calculations.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes.AllForNonNumeric
member.summary: A convenience for requesting all available summary calculations for non-numeric data.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimeBasedEventSource
member.summary: The AFTimeBasedEventSource is a base class that can be used for data references which do not natively support streaming events for an but supports . AFTimeBasedEventSource periodically polls data from in the pipe and caches the result. When the GetUpdateEvents/GetObserverEvents of the pipe is called, AFTimeBasedEventSource extracts the events up to current time + from its cache to be returned to the caller.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimeBasedEventSource.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new event source

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimeBasedEventSource.Dispose
member.summary: Cleans up resources

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation
member.summary: Defines the timestamp returned for a value when a summary calculation is done.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation.Auto
member.summary: The timestamp returned will be the minimum or maximum time for those summary types, or, the start time of the summary period otherwise.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation.EarliestTime
member.summary: The timestamp returned will be for the start of the summary period.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation.MostRecentTime
member.summary: The timestamp returned will be for the end of the summary period.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFUpdateOption
member.summary: Indicates how to treat duplicate values in the archive, when supported by the Data Reference.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFUpdateOption.Replace
member.summary: Add the value to the archive. If any values exist at the same time, will overwrite one of them and set its Substituted flag.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFUpdateOption.Insert
member.summary: Add the value to the archive. Any existing values at the same time are not overwritten.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFUpdateOption.NoReplace
member.summary: Add the value to the archive only if no value exists at the same time. If a value already exists for that time, the passed value is ignored.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFUpdateOption.ReplaceOnly
member.summary: Replace an existing value in the archive at the specified time. If no existing value is found, the passed value is ignored.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFUpdateOption.InsertNoCompression
member.summary: Add the value to the archive without compression. If this value is written to the snapshot, the previous snapshot value will be written to the archive, without regard to compression settings. Note that if a subsequent snapshot value is written without the InsertNoCompression option, the value added with the InsertNoCompression option is still subject to compression.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFUpdateOption.Remove
member.summary: Remove the value from the archive if a value exists at the passed time.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Data.IAFDataProvider
member.summary: An interface for providing cache-enabled instances that can be used to generate inputs for calculations.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Data.IAFDataProvider.TryGetItem(OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFAttribute,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFData@)
member.summary: Acquires a cache-enabled instance if one is available.
member.param: The attribute to get an instance for.

The query date used to find the object. Specify or AFTime.MaxValue for most recent versions of the objects.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: The in the which matches the unique identifier at the specified . If the object does not exist, then will be returned.

An object representing the starting time for the search. The must be less than or equal to the . The parameter will control whether the comparison will be performed against the event frame's or .
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

An object representing the ending time for the search. The must be greater than or equal to the . The parameter will control whether the comparison will be performed against the event frame's or .
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

The event frame name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.

The name filter string of an in the event frame's collection. Uses same filtering rules as specified for the parameter. To obtain an exact match to a specific element, specify the element's ID using a format that includes the opening and closing braces, such as ID.ToString("B").
Specify that returned event frames must have this category. To not filter by event frame category, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that returned event frames must have this template or a template derived from this template. To not filter by event frame template, then specify for this parameter.

Specify that returned event frames must have an in the event frame's collection must have this template or a template derived from this template. To not filter by a referenced element template, then specify for this parameter.
An array of duration queries that are ANDed together to find the desired objects. To not filter by duration, set this parameter to .
Specifies if the search should include objects nested further than the immediate children of the searchRoot.
The starting index (zero based) of the items to be returned.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection. This value should not be changed between calls when attempting to get the next page of items.
The order that the returned collection is sorted. This value should not be changed between calls when attempting to get the next page of items.
The maximum number of objects to be returned per call (the page size).
Specify that returned event frames must have this category. To not filter by event frame category, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that returned event frames must have this template or a template derived from this template. To not filter by event frame template, then specify for this parameter.
member.returns: Returns a collection containing the specified page of objects which match the specified string and filters.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrame.LoadEventFrames(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.Guid[],System.Object)
member.summary: Loads the objects with the specified unique identifiers at the specified query date.
member.param: The to search for the desired objects.
An array of the unique identifiers of the objects to find.

The query date used to load the objects. Specify or AFTime.MaxValue for most recent versions of the objects.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: A list of the objects in the which match the unique identifier at the specified . If the object cannot be found, it will not be returned in the list.

member.summary: Loads the specified list objects.
member.param: The list of event frames to be fully loaded. If , then this method does nothing. All event frames in the list must be from the same .

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrame.LoadEventFramesToDepth(System.Collections.Generic.IList{OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrame},System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads the specified list objects and their child event frames to the hierarchical depth specified.
member.param: The list of root event frames to be loaded. If , then this method does nothing. All event frames in the list must be from the same .
This parameter is ignored and will always perform a full load in this release.

Specifies the number of levels of the event frame hierarchy to load past the level of the event frames in the collection passed in. For example, a depth parameter of 2 would indicate that all child event frames and grandchild event frames of the specified event frames would be loaded.
Specifies the maximum number of objects to load. Once the maximum number of objects is reached, the load will terminate.
member.returns: The list of event frames returned is a list of all child event frames loaded at all depths. Even though each in the list are loaded, they are not included in the returned list.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrameSearchMode
member.summary: The event frame search mode is an enumeration of the possible values for specifying the search criteria for event frames from a time.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrameSearchMode.None
member.summary: This is the value of an uninitialized search mode.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrameSearchMode.BackwardFromStartTime
member.summary: Event frames with a start time less than or equal to the time specified in the search (moving backward in time) are returned from the search. Also known as "Starting Before".

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrameSearchMode.ForwardFromStartTime
member.summary: Event frames with a start time greater than or equal to the time specified in the search (moving forward in time) are returned from the search. Also known as "Starting After".

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrameSearchMode.BackwardFromEndTime
member.summary: Event frames with an end time less than or equal to the time specified in the search (moving backward in time) are returned from the search. Also known as "Ending Before".

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrameSearchMode.ForwardFromEndTime
member.summary: Event frames with an end time greater than or equal to the time specified in the search (moving forward in time) are returned from the search. Also know as "Ending After".

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrameSearchMode.BackwardInProgress
member.summary: Event frames with a start time less than or equal to the time specified in the search (moving backward in time) that are still in progress (an end time set to ) are returned from the search. Also known as "Starting Before and In Progress".

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.EventFrame.AFEventFrameSearchMode.ForwardInProgress
member.summary: Event frames with a start time greater than or equal to the time specified in the search (moving forward in time) that are still in progress (an end time set to ) are returned from the search. Also known as "Starting After and In Progress".

The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". member.summary: Retrieves a list of objects that match the specified filtering conditions.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.
Determines how the and parameters are treated when searching for transfer objects to be included in the returned collection.

An object representing the starting time for the search. The must be less than or equal to the . The parameter will control whether the comparison will be performed against the transfer's or .
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

An object representing the ending time for the search. The must be greater than or equal to the . The parameter will control whether the comparison will be performed against the event frame's or .
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

The transfer name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
If not , only AFTransfers with the specified will be returned.
If not , only AFTransfers with the specified will be returned.
Specify that returned transfers must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that returned transfers must have this template or a template derived from this template. To not filter by element template, then specify for this parameter.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns a collection containing the specified page of objects which match the specified string and filters.

member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

An object representing the starting time to begin the search. The search may compare against either the or of the transfer based on the parameter.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.
The maximum number of transfers to be returned. More than the specified number may be returned if multiple items have the same for the last transfer returned.
Indicates the direction in time from the or to proceed when returning transfers.
If not an empty string, only transfers which match the supplied filter on their name property will be returned.
If not , only AFTransfers with the specified will be returned.
If not , only AFTransfers with the specified will be returned.
Specify that returned transfers must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.

member.summary: Retrieves a list of objects limited to the specified count beginning at the requested start time in the specified direction.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

An object representing the starting time to begin the search.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.
The maximum number of transfers to be returned. More than the specified number may be returned if multiple items have the same for the last transfer returned.

Indicates the direction in time from the start time to proceed when returning transfers. If , then transfers greater than or equal to the start time (moving forward in time) are returned. If , then transfers less than or equal to the start time (moving backward in time) are returned.
If not an empty string, only transfers which match the supplied filter on their name property will be returned.
If not , only AFTransfers with the specified will be returned.
If not , only AFTransfers with the specified will be returned.
Specify that returned transfers must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.
Specify that returned transfers must have this template or a template derived from this template. To not filter by element template, then specify for this parameter.
member.returns: Returns the list of objects which match the search criteria.

member.summary: Performs a text search within the to retrieve a collection of objects that match the specified query string.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The query string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection of objects which match the specified string.
