member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Notification.AFNotification.FindNotification(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.Guid,System.Object)
member.summary: Retrieves the object with the specified unique identifier at the specified query date.
member.param: The to search for the desired object.
The unique identifier of the object to find.

The query date used to find the object. Specify or AFTime.MaxValue for most recent versions of the objects.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: The in the which matches the unique identifier at the specified .

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Notification.AFNotification.FindNotifications(OSIsoft.AF.AFDatabase,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFCategory,OSIsoft.AF.Asset.AFElementTemplate,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a search within the to retrieve a non-paged collection of objects that match the specified query string and additional filters.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The name filter string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specify that returned notifications must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.

Specify that returned notifications must have this template or a template derived from this template. You can specify to return notifications that do not have any template. To not filter by element template, then specify for this parameter.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns a collection containing the first page of objects which match the specified string and filters.

One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specify that returned notifications must have this category. To not filter by element category, then specify for this parameter.

Specify that returned notifications must have this template or a template derived from this template. You can specify to return notifications that do not have any template. To not filter by element template, then specify for this parameter.
The that is the target of the analysis of the desired objects.
The that is to receive the the desired objects.
The of the desired objects must match this status. Specify to not search by status.
The starting index (zero based) of the items to be returned.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection. This value should not be changed between calls when attempting to get the next page of items.
The order that the returned collection is sorted. This value should not be changed between calls when attempting to get the next page of items.
The maximum number of objects to be returned per call (the page size).
member.returns: Returns a collection containing the specified page of objects which match the specified string and filters.

The query date used to load the objects. Specify or AFTime.MaxValue for most recent versions of the objects.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: Returns a collection containing any on the with an id that matches an entry in . If no is found for an id entry, there will be no corresponding entry in the returned collection.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Notification.AFNotificationContactTemplate.FindNotificationContactTemplates(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFSearchField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a text search within the to retrieve a collection of objects that match the specified query string.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The query string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection of objects which match the specified string.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Notification.AFNotificationTemplate.FindNotificationTemplate(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.Guid)
member.summary: Retrieves the object with the specified unique identifier at the AFTime.MaxValue query date.
member.param: The to search for the desired object.
The unique identifier of the object to find.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Notification.AFNotificationTemplate.FindNotificationTemplate(OSIsoft.AF.PISystem,System.Guid,System.Object)
member.summary: Retrieves the object with the specified unique identifier at the specified query date.
member.param: The to search for the desired object.
The unique identifier of the object to find.

The query date used to find the object. Specify or AFTime.MaxValue for most recent versions of the objects.
The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to AFTime.Now.
member.returns: The in the which matches the unique identifier at the specified .

member.summary: This enumeration defines the possible values for the .

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIBufferHealthStatus.Ok
member.summary: Indicates buffering is functioning normally. This status is used in to indicate normal condition.

member.summary: Indicates a buffering situation that may need attention. This status is used in to indicate warning condition, for example disk space may be getting low.

member.summary: Indicates that there is a problem with buffering. This status is used in to indicate the presence errors.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIBufferHealthStatus.Critical
member.summary: Indicates a critical error condition with buffering. This status is used in to indicate the presence of critical errors.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIBufferHealthStatus.NotRunning
member.summary: Indicates that the buffering system is not running or not present. This status is used in to indicate buffering system is not running or not present.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIBufferHealthStatus.Disabled
member.summary: Indicates that buffering functionality is disabled. This status is used in to indicate that buffering is disabled.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIBufferHealthStatus.NotConfigured
member.summary: Indicates that buffering functionality is not yet configured. This status is used in to indicate that buffering is not yet configured.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIBufferHealthStatus.FailedToInitialize
member.summary: Indicates that buffering initialization has failed. This status is used in to indicate that buffering initialization has failed.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIBufferHealthStatus.Unknown
member.summary: Indicates the buffering status is unknown. This status is used in to indicate an unknown buffering condition.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIPoint.FilteredSummaries(OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeSpan,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSampleType,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeSpan,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation)
member.summary: This method, when supplied a filter expression that evaluates to true or false, evaluates it over the passed time range. For the time ranges where the expression evaluates to true, the method calculates the requested summaries on the source attribute.
member.param: The bounding time range over which the filtered summary intervals are computed.

param.name: summaryDuration
param.para: The duration of each summary interval. If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the summary durations will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.

When a positive duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the summary intervals.

If a negative duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the summary intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the summary duration sign.

member.param: A filter expression that follows the performance equation syntax.

When the is , it specifies how often the filter expression is evaluated when computing the summary for an interval.
An enumeration value that specifies how the timestamp is calculated.
member.returns: A dictionary of , indexed by the specific .
member.exception: The cannot be .
Error returned by the PI Data Archive.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIPoint.FindAttributeNames(System.String)
member.summary: Find the loaded PIPoint attribute names based upon a filter.
member.param:
The filter to use for the list of PIPoint attribute names to be returned.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
member.returns: Returns a list of PIPoint attribute names based upon the specified filter.

On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.

When a positive interval is specified, the interval calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the interval repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the calculation intervals.

If a negative interval is specified, the interval calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the interval repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the calculation intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the interval sign.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIPoint.Summaries(OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeSpan,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation)
member.summary: Returns several summaries over a time range for each interval within the range.
member.param: The bounding time range over which the summary intervals are computed.

param.name: summaryDuration
param.para: The duration of each summary interval. If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the summary durations will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.

When a positive duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the summary intervals.

If a negative duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the summary intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the summary duration sign.

member.param: A flag which specifies one or more summaries to compute for each interval over the time range
Specifies the method of evaluating the data over the time range.
A flag indicating what how to calculate a timestamp for each interval.
member.returns: A dictionary of , indexed by the specific .
member.exception: The cannot be .
Error returned by the PI Data Archive.

member.summary: This method, when supplied a filter expression that evaluates to true or false, evaluates it over the passed time range. For the time ranges where the expression evaluates to true, the method calculates the requested summaries on the source attribute.
member.param: The bounding time range over which the filtered summary intervals are computed.

param.name: summaryDuration
param.para: The duration of each summary interval. If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the summary durations will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.

When a positive duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the summary intervals.

If a negative duration is specified, the summary calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the duration repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the summary intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the summary duration sign.

member.param: A filter expression that follows the performance equation syntax.
A flag which specifies one or more summaries to compute for each interval over the time range
Specifies the method of evaluating the data over the time range.
Together with the , specifies how and how often the filter expression is evaluated.
When the is , it specifies how often the filter expression is evaluated when computing the summary for an interval.
An enumeration value that specifies how the timestamp is calculated.
Contains the paging configuration parameters for the request.

returns.para: An enumerable of summaries results for each in the list. The results are not guaranteed to match the order of the , and duplicate points in the list will not produce a duplicate result. The results can be mapped back to the corresponding PI Point using the property on each result.

The order of the results are predictable; however, if you need the results in the same order as the attribute list, then consider using a dictionary keyed by PI Point to construct a list in the same order.

The points in the list are broken up by their corresponding PI Data Archive. A bulk call is made against each PI Data Archive in parallel. The results are made available as they are returned from the PI Data Archive in the order that the bulk calls were made.
The following example shows a list of points including duplicates from three different PI Data Archives:
This table shows the order that the results would be returned:

Since the first point is on the Contoso PI Data Archive, it is the first PI Data Archive to receive a bulk call; therefore, all Contoso point results will be returned first. Duplicate points do not produce a duplicate result, so the duplicate Contoso Lobby_Room_Temperature does not produce a second return value. After the Contoso results have been returned, the Northwind results are returned followed by the AdventureWorks results.

param.para: The Sample interval. If specified in hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds, the time intervals will be evenly spaced UTC time intervals. Longer interval types are interpreted using wall clock rules and are time zone dependent. For example, an interval created with the string "24h" means using an evenly spaced 24 UTC hour interval between each event. On the other hand, an interval created with the string "1d" would return an interval shorter or longer than 24 hours if the interval encompasses a Daylight Savings Time change.

When a positive interval is specified, the interval calculation begins at the earliest bounding time in the and applies the interval repeatedly in time ascending direction to generate the calculation intervals.

If a negative interval is specified, the interval calculation begins at the latest bounding time in the and applies the interval repeatedly in time descending direction to generate the calculation intervals. Note that the order of values returned will still be reflected by the , regardless of the interval sign.

member.param: A filter expression that follows the performance equation syntax.

Contains the paging configuration parameters for the request.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIPointList.Summary(OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFSummaryTypes,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFCalculationBasis,OSIsoft.AF.Data.AFTimestampCalculation,OSIsoft.AF.PI.PIPagingConfiguration)
member.summary: Returns several summaries over a single time range for each in the list.
member.param: The time range over which to compute the summary.
A flag which specifies one or more summaries to compute over the time range.
Specifies the method of evaluating the data over the time range.
A flag indicating what how to calculate a timestamp for each interval.
Contains the paging configuration parameters for the request.

returns.para: An enumerable of summary results for each in the list. The results are not guaranteed to match the order of the , and duplicate points in the list will not produce a duplicate result. The results can be mapped back to the corresponding PI Point using the property on each result.

The order of the results are predictable; however, if you need the results in the same order as the attribute list, then consider using a dictionary keyed by PI Point to construct a list in the same order.

The points in the list are broken up by their corresponding PI Data Archive. A bulk call is made against each PI Data Archive in parallel. The results are made available as they are returned from the PI Data Archive in the order that the bulk calls were made.
The following example shows a list of points including duplicates from three different PI Data Archives:
This table shows the order that the results would be returned:

Since the first point is on the Contoso PI Data Archive, it is the first PI Data Archive to receive a bulk call; therefore, all Contoso point results will be returned first. Duplicate points do not produce a duplicate result, so the duplicate Contoso Lobby_Room_Temperature does not produce a second return value. After the Contoso results have been returned, the Northwind results are returned followed by the AdventureWorks results.

member.name: T:OSIsoft.AF.Search.AFSearchOperator
member.summary: Search operator for based searches, , and .

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Search.AFSearchOperator.Equal
member.summary: For an based query, the filter value is equal to the specified AFSearchToken.Value. For an , the attribute value is equal to the specified AFAttributeValueQuery.AttributeValue. For an , the event frame's duration is equal to the specified AFDurationQuery.Duration.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Search.AFSearchOperator.NotEqual
member.summary: For an based query, the filter value is not equal to the specified AFSearchToken.Value. For an , the attribute value is not equal to the specified AFAttributeValueQuery.AttributeValue. For an , the event frame's duration is not equal to the specified AFDurationQuery.Duration.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Search.AFSearchOperator.LessThan
member.summary: For an based query, the filter value is less than to the specified AFSearchToken.Value. For an , the attribute value is less than to the specified AFAttributeValueQuery.AttributeValue. For an , the event frame's duration is less than to the specified AFDurationQuery.Duration.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Search.AFSearchOperator.GreaterThan
member.summary: For an based query, the filter value is greater than to the specified AFSearchToken.Value. For an , the attribute value is greater than to the specified AFAttributeValueQuery.AttributeValue. For an , the event frame's duration is greater than to the specified AFDurationQuery.Duration.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Search.AFSearchOperator.LessThanOrEqual
member.summary: For an based query, the filter value is less than or equal to the specified AFSearchToken.Value. For an , the attribute value is less than or equal to the specified AFAttributeValueQuery.AttributeValue. For an , the event frame's duration is less than or equal to the specified AFDurationQuery.Duration.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Search.AFSearchOperator.GreaterThanOrEqual
member.summary: For an based query, the filter value is greater than or equal to the specified AFSearchToken.Value. For an , the attribute value is greater than or equal to the specified AFAttributeValueQuery.AttributeValue. For an , the event frame's duration is greater than or equal to the specified AFDurationQuery.Duration.

member.name: F:OSIsoft.AF.Search.AFSearchOperator.In
member.summary: For an , the attribute value is IN the array of values specified in the AFAttributeValueQuery.AttributeValue. For an based query or , this operation is not valid.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTime.#ctor(System.Object,OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTime)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the AFTime structure to the specified value representation of time using the information and formatting style, providing a default if necessary.
member.param: Converts different types of objects, including PISDK.PITime objects, to AFTime. A will return an AFTime representing the current time.

This parameter serves as the reference time to be used when the parameter contain a relative string reference (e.g. "*", "Today", etc.) instead of using the current time. The server time can be used as a reference time by specifying PISystem.ServerTime, PIServer.ServerTime, or AFAttribute.ServerTime for this parameter. If the parameter cannot be converted to a valid time, then the value of the new AFTime instance will be set to the time specified for this parameter.

param.name: time
param.param: Converts different types of objects, including PISDK.PITime objects, to AFTime. A will return an AFTime representing the current time.

param.name: defaultTime
param.param: This parameter serves as the reference time to be used when the parameter contain a relative string reference (e.g. "*", "Today", etc.) instead of using the current time. The server time can be used as a reference time by specifying PISystem.ServerTime, PIServer.ServerTime, or AFAttribute.ServerTime for this parameter. If the parameter cannot be converted to a valid time, then the value of the new AFTime instance will be set to the time specified for this parameter.

param.name: provider
param.para: An object that supplies culture-specific formatting information about the time string parameters. The can be used to provide the to be used when parsing. The can be used when parsing PI SDK locale independent time strings.

member.param: A string containing the date, time, and interval to convert.

The reference time used when the time string parameters contain a relative reference (e.g. "*", "Today", etc.) instead of using the current time. The server time can be used as a reference time by specifying PISystem.ServerTime, PIServer.ServerTime or AFAttribute.ServerTime for this parameter.

param.name: provider
param.para: An object that supplies culture-specific formatting information about the time string parameters. The can be used to provide the to be used when parsing. The can be used when parsing PI SDK locale independent time strings.
If or an is specified with the as , then will be used first when parsing the time strings. If the parsing fails in this case, then a second attempt is made to parse using .

member.returns: The value equivalent to the date and time string contained in if the conversion succeeded, or if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the parameter does not contain a valid string representation of a data and time.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRange.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new AFTimeRange object with the specified string representations of start and end times.

param.name: startTime
param.para: The starting time of the time range represented by this object, specified in a string format. Strings are interpreted as local time unless it also contains a time zone indicator, such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". PI Time formats ("*", "T", "*-1h", "+3d", etc.) are also supported.

Relative parameter rules:
If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified), then the start time will be relative to the end time.
If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified) and the does not start with "+" or "-", then the end time will be relative to the start time.
If neither of these conditions are true, then the times are not relative to each other.

param.name: endTime
param.para: The ending time of the time range represented by this object, specified in a string format. Strings are interpreted as local time unless it also contains a time zone indicator, such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". PI Time formats ("*", "T", "*-1h", "+3d", etc.) are also supported.

Relative parameter rules:
If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified), then the start time will be relative to the end time.
If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified) and the does not start with "+" or "-", then the end time will be relative to the start time.
If neither of these conditions are true, then the times are not relative to each other.

member.summary: Converts the specified local date and time string representations of the start and end times to its equivalent by using the specified reference time and culture-specific formatting information.

param.name: startTime
param.para: The starting time of the time range represented by this object, specified in a string format. Strings are interpreted as local time unless it also contains a time zone indicator, such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". PI Time formats ("*", "T", "*-1h", "+3d", etc.) are also supported.

Relative parameter rules:
If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified), then the start time will be relative to the end time.
If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified) and the does not start with "+" or "-", then the end time will be relative to the start time.
If neither of these conditions are true, then the times are not relative to each other.

param.name: endTime
param.para: The ending time of the time range represented by this object, specified in a string format. Strings are interpreted as local time unless it also contains a time zone indicator, such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". PI Time formats ("*", "T", "*-1h", "+3d", etc.) are also supported.

If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified) and the does not start with "+" or "-", then the end time will be relative to the start time.
If neither of these conditions are true, then the times are not relative to each other.

member.param: The reference time used when the time string parameters contain a relative reference (e.g. "*", "Today", etc.) instead of using the current time. The server time can be used as a reference time by specifying PISystem.ServerTime, PIServer.ServerTime or AFAttribute.ServerTime for this parameter.

member.summary: Converts the specified local date and time string representations of the start and end times to its equivalent by using the specified reference time and culture-specific formatting information, and returns a value that indicates whether the conversion succeeded.

param.name: startTime
param.para: The starting time of the time range represented by this object, specified in a string format. Strings are interpreted as local time unless it also contains a time zone indicator, such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". PI Time formats ("*", "T", "*-1h", "+3d", etc.) are also supported.

Relative parameter rules:
If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified), then the start time will be relative to the end time.
If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified) and the does not start with "+" or "-", then the end time will be relative to the start time.
If neither of these conditions are true, then the times are not relative to each other.

param.name: endTime
param.para: The ending time of the time range represented by this object, specified in a string format. Strings are interpreted as local time unless it also contains a time zone indicator, such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". PI Time formats ("*", "T", "*-1h", "+3d", etc.) are also supported.

Relative parameter rules:
If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified), then the start time will be relative to the end time.
If the starts with "+" or "-" (without a "*" specified) and the does not start with "+" or "-", then the end time will be relative to the start time.
If neither of these conditions are true, then the times are not relative to each other.

member.param: The reference time used when the time string parameters contain a relative reference (e.g. "*", "Today", etc.) instead of using the current time. The server time can be used as a reference time by specifying PISystem.ServerTime, PIServer.ServerTime or AFAttribute.ServerTime for this parameter.

param.name: provider
param.para: An object that supplies culture-specific formatting information about the time string parameters. The can be used to provide the to be used when parsing. The can be used when parsing PI SDK locale independent time strings.
If or an is specified with the as , then will be used first when parsing the time strings. If the parsing fails in this case, then a second attempt is made to parse using .

member.param: When this method returns, contains the value equivalent to the date and time strings contained in and if the conversion succeeded. If conversion failed, then a default is returned. The conversion fails if the or parameters do not contain a valid string representation of a data and time.
member.returns: Returns if and parameters were converted successfully; otherwise, .

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRuleEvent.SetEndTime(System.Object)
member.summary: Set the time that represents the time that the period ended.
member.param: The new end time for the period. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Time.AFTimeRuleEvent.SetStartTime(System.Object)
member.summary: Set the time that represents the time that the period started.
member.param: The new start time for the period. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

member.summary: This interface defines the properties and methods for objects which support a time period.

member.name: P:OSIsoft.AF.Time.IAFTimePeriod.EndTime
member.summary: This read-only property represents the end time of the period.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Time.IAFTimePeriod.SetEndTime(System.Object)
member.summary: Set the time that represents the time that the period ended.
member.param: The new end time for the period. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.Time.IAFTimePeriod.SetStartTime(System.Object)
member.summary: Set the time that represents the time that the period started.
member.param: The new start time for the period. The value may be an , , PITime, , or numeric. A (or a DATE from COM or VB6 clients) must be expressed as the coordinated universal time (UTC). An integer numeric represents the number of ticks (100-nanosecond intervals) since January 1, 0001. A floating point numeric represents the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 UTC. A is interpreted as local time, unless it contains a time zone indicator such as a trailing "Z" or "GMT". Strings will be interpreted with the AFTime.Parse Overload methods so that relative formats with intervals ("*", "T+3h", etc.) are also supported. Intervals are relative to the object's QueryDate.

member.name: P:OSIsoft.AF.Time.IAFTimePeriod.StartTime
member.summary: This read-only property represents the start time of the period.

member.summary: This is a read-only property which returns the period's and values as a time range.

member.name: M:OSIsoft.AF.UnitsOfMeasure.UOM.FindUOMs(OSIsoft.AF.UnitsOfMeasure.UOMDatabase,System.String,OSIsoft.AF.AFSearchField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortField,OSIsoft.AF.AFSortOrder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a text search within the to retrieve a collection of objects that match the specified query string.
member.param: The to search for the requested objects.

The query string used for finding objects.
The query string (or match pattern) can include regular characters and wildcard characters. Regular characters must match exactly the characters specified in the query string. Wildcard characters can be matched with arbitrary fragments of the query string. Wildcard characters can be escaped using the single backslash (\) character. Use a double backslash (\\) to match a single backslash. The syntax of the query string has the following rules:
If or empty string, then everything will be matched.
If no wildcards, then an exact match on the query string is performed.
Wildcard * can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches zero or more characters.
Wildcard ? can be placed anywhere in the query string and matches exactly one character.
One character in a set of characters are matched by placing them within [ ]. For example, a[bc] would match 'ab' or 'ac', but it would not match 'ad' or 'abd'.
One character in a set of characters are not matched by placing them within [! ]. For example, a[!bc] would match 'ad', but it would not match 'ab', 'ac', or 'abd'.
Specifies which of the object's properties are searched.
The field or property of the object used to sort the returned collection.
The order that the returned collection is sorted.
The maximum number of objects to be returned.
member.returns: Returns the collection of objects which match the specified string.
